Subject: Re: CPPN node bloat
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=7pf7di_XWfDM_oSJDI1o3-ech3sc6-BPTqZyYAbhZvfLpPnAIvME

Jeff, first, if fitness is stagnant, then the system should be increasing=
 the average number of nodes (though not necessarily the number of nodes in=
 the champ).  In a stagnant situation, you do not have information (i.e. a =
gradient) suggesting which direction is right to go.  Therefore, the most p=
rincipled response is to expand your options while never putting all your e=
ggs in one basket.  When fitness is stagnant, we cannot know if further sea=
rch within the currently dimensionality might eventually find a solution, o=
r if the current dimensionality is insufficient and contains no solution at=
 all.  In the latter case, the number of nodes and connections would need t=
o ascend to higher dimensionality.  Because we do not know which case we ar=
e in when stagnation occurs, the best idea is to try both:  Some species st=
art arriving with bigger networks while others keep searching in the same o=
ld spaces.  Thus, we would expect the *range* of sizes to increase along wi=
th the average size.  

Your situation with nondeterminism is probably some=
what similar, causing the average size of solutions to go up because of sta=
gnation.  However, because the champion will keep changing with the randomi=
zed evaluation, you will observe this phenomenon in the champion itself.  T=
he more noisy it is, the more it is probably observable (i.e. because the m=
ore "random" it is who happens to look best at any given time, in effect le=
ading to a kind of sampling of the population through the champion).  

Of =
course, that may not be a complete explanation for the steep angle of the i=
ncline.  I would guess that nondeterminism is also causing a general unheal=
thiness about the evolutionary process overall. Nondeterminism is highly de=
structive to evolutionary algorithms.  This issue is controversial (even wi=
thin my own group!) but my personal opinion is one should avoid nondetermin=
ism unless it is absolutely essential.  For example, you can choose a rando=
m order of examples but then subject everyone to the same random set - a ki=
nd of "deterministic randomness."  Of course, you are banking on the impart=
iality of randomness to give you maximal generality, but it will often be o=
utweighed by its unhealthy side effects on the population.  So I'm guessing=
 that part of the phenomenon is just a side-effect of an inconsistent evalu=
ation scheme leading to relative chaos.

There may also be more to it; it m=
erits further investigation as well.

ken 



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello Ken-
> 
> I am plotting the number=
 of CPPN nodes in the generation champion.
> 
> This fitness function is no=
t deterministic (here I am running the bit
> mirroring problem, and I rando=
mly generate 10 different sets of inputs per
> organism per generation). If=
 you look closely at the fitness graph of the
> first image you can see tha=
t the fitness line is jumping around a lot
> (though the variation is low).=

> 
> In the second plot, interestingly, the two runs that have a constant
=
> environment (which happens to be deterministic) do not see the huge incre=
ase
> in CPPN number (it levels out at a healthy level of about 30). The ch=
anging
> environments, however, have the runaway CPPN bloat.
> 
> Is there =
something in NEAT that causes bloat unless you have elitism
> counteracting=
 it? If so, my non-deterministic environments might prevent
> elitism from =
fighting bloat.
> 
> Have any of you ever turned off elitism and looked at =
the effect on genome
> size? This may be affecting NEAT as much as HyperNEA=
T. Alternately, have any
> of you looked at genome size in non-deterministi=
c environments?
> 
> Also of interest: I tend to plot the genome node numbe=
r only for the
> champion, which may be held down due to elitism (when fitn=
ess flat lines).
> Have any of you plotted the average number of genome nod=
es? That number may
> really increase, especially once fitness stagnates...=
if what I am seeing is
> not pathological. 
> 
> Thanks for any thoughts an=
yone has.
> 
> Kind regards,
> Jeff Clune

> > Jeff, one thing I don't completely understand about your graphs=
 (e.g. graph 1)
> > is that the number of nodes in the champion goes up eve=
n when fitness is not
> > going up.  If you have elitism, wouldn't the same=
 champion stick around
> > unchanged?  Perhaps you are seeing that new indi=
viduals occasionally come in
> > with the same fitness as the champion, but=
 it would be very surprising if that
> > is happening on every single gener=
ation.  Yet that would seem to be the only
> > possibility with the number =
of champion nodes going up so rapidly even while
> > fitness is flatlined. =
 So what is going on during the fitness plateau?  Which

 are being measured to get the node counts?

umber

of the

su.edu/~jclune/delme/CPPN-Node-Bloat-1.png

lly pathological, with almost 25 CPPN nodes being added
> >> every 100 gene=
rations, such as here:

de-Bloat-2.png

 environment and those runs where
> >> the CPPN node count flatlines (at a =
healthy level) are in a constant
> >> environment.
> >> 
> >> Are any of yo=
u seeing such bloat?
> >>

to a crawl, because running
> >> populations with 200-node genomes is reall=
y slow. Moreover, I doubt
> >> evolution can make too much progress with th=
at many nodes (although I have
> >> seen fitness continue to increase even =
with such large genomes).
> >>

eProbability from 0.03 to 0.003 and

of the line, but it still linearly
> >> increases. The good news is that it=
 does not affect fitness to much.
